newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Taiwan to introduce, import 98-RON petrol in 1998.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan to introduce, import 98-RON petrol in 1998.

text.p: Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp (CPC) is planning to introduce 98-octane gasoline next year and is expected to import at least one cargo per month of the higher grade gasoline, a company official said on Friday.
"It is not a government directive," the official said on the move. "It is because the consumers want a higher RON."
Taiwan currently consumes 95-octane and 92-octane unleaded and leaded gasoline.
The new grade is expected to take up around 15 to 20 percent of the gasoline market share, the official said.
He said CPC is currently studying possible sources for the 98-octane gasoline as it is planning to import around 250,000-barrels per month of the new grade.
"CPC can produce 90-percent of the 98-octane requirements...the remaining 10-percent we will import," he said.

He said the four reformers at the Kaohsiung refinery totalling 90,000-barrels-per-day (bpd) and the two at the Taoyuan refinery with a capacity of 45,000-bpd, were capable of producing the higher grade.
Currently, CPC imports on average two to three 250,000-barrel cargoes of 95-octane unleaded and leaded reformate.
